newsitem.title: FRANCE: French daily flouts no-poll law citing Internet.
newsitem.headline: French daily flouts no-poll law citing Internet.

text.p: A French newspaper on Friday flouted a law barring publication of opinion polls just ahead of elections, branding the rules hypocritical when such surveys are available on the Internet.

The Republique des Pyrenees daily in the southwestern town of Pau carried the results of a CSA poll along with an editorial entitled "In the name of equality", condemning the 20-year-old law banning the appearance of polls in the week before national elections.

"It's the electoral law that's out of date, it should be modified," Jean-Marcel Bouguereau wrote in the editorial. The paper risks a 500,000 franc fine ($88,000) for publishing a poll just ahead of Sunday's first round of National Assembly elections. A runoff vote takes place on June 1.

He said confidential polls taken in recent days were available on the Internet and people like politicians, stock brokers and journalists all had access to surveys denied to French citizens under a law designed to avoid swaying voters.

The polls, or rumours of them, are a major factor moving the Paris stock market ahead of the election. Polls taken before the blackout all gave the ruling centre-right at least a narrow lead over the left.
The law cannot prevent publication abroad, boosting sales of newspapers like Switzerland's Tribune de Geneve, available just over the border. Britain's Daily Telegraph has also published a poll.

The Internet computer network has blasted a new hole in the law for the 300,000 subscribers in France. The Tribune de Geneve's site publishing polls, "www.edicom.ch/tdg/", has been swamped by French cyberspace visitors.
Andre Santini, spokesman for the Union for French Democracy (UDF) which is the junior partner in the ruling coalition, urged a review of French law.
"Technologies have evolved...I wonder if we're in the process of treating the French people like infants," he told France 3 television. "I think that we must reflect on the text of this law."
Polling institutes fired off a last burst of public surveys last Saturday, hours before the ban came into effect. It extends until the June 1 run-off.
Similar bans apply in countries like Belgium, Spain and Italy. But Britain, Germany and the United States have no restrictions on polls.
